column3: A major appeal of Open Science is the capacity to harness collective intelligence and face big scientific challenges, unmet when researchers are working in isolation. Below is a list of such projects. Work your way through the list (up to you if you wish to divide and conquer, work in couples or as a group) to discover the projects. Apply your score (1-5 low-to-high score), using 10 of the Vienna Open Science Principles (Do read here: https://viennaprinciples.org/) to rank the projects’ ‘openness’. Add a few comments on what you appreciated and what you think could be improved in these projects.
Premise of the project in one simple phrase!

column6: 3/5 (1491 publications but no access to all of them)

column13: 4/5 (this project canlead to progress in the understanding of the brain, brain medicine, and brain-inspired technologies)
column15: the website is accessible and organised, parterships are open to everyone willing to contibute, the community is diverse (students, teachers, researchers..), diversity (accross europe), these studies can lead to a massive posistive impact in medicine
column16: we don't have access to the data used in the publications, we can access some tools but still not transparent enough,

column3: Worldwide network of scientists sorting fact from fiction in science based media coverage in order to help readers know which news to trust.
column7: 5/5 (we have enough info to use their data for other studies)

column3: Open source project dedicated to provide open access to world's first virtual organism
column4: 3/5 (while mostly accesible, there was some documents that required me to ask for permission to access)
column7: 4/5 (provides materials for others to understand it)
column10: 3/5 (While they try to explain through a variety of resources, people who are not familiar with coding might have difficulties understanding)
column11: 5/5 (There is a section that provides information on how to get involved, volunteer, support or donate)
column13: 4/5 (it's a well-intentioned project that aims provide open access to a virtual model)
column15: Very innovative project. It's a very innovative idea to create the world's first virtual organism to understand other complex systems such as the human brain
column16: Some concepts and terms are hard to understand for people who are not well-versed in coding. There are not many publications.

column3: NGO collecting data on environmental radiation and Air Quality
column6: 1/5 (the last publication was in 2017, it's not their primary goal, but still)
column8: 5/5 (all information about tools they use to collect data are listed, there's a map where you can track it live)
column9: 3/5 (it's easy to understand who is behind the work, but there's no real feedback info)
column11: 5/5 (it's an NGO, which means they invite volunteers to work with them, they are listed on the website, it's a diverse group)
column12: 1/5 (no evaluations are presented, this is not the goal of the NGO)
column15: The website is organized and detailes, it's easy to understand who are the people behind the work, it's easy to understand the stakeholders? the information in extremely useful for public and researchers.
